Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Small: Facilitating Mentoring in Peer Health Communities through Social Matching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the experience of serious illness, patients develop substantial expertise about managing their personal health. When experienced patients ("mentors") share their expertise with individuals who are facing a health situation for the first time, they find considerable value is this help. Peer health communities offer a broad base of such "patient expertise", yet people can miss out on this valuable resource because, all too often, peer mentoring is difficult to obtain and yields advice that doesn't quite fit one's personal situation or context.

The efforts within this project are focused on overcoming this challenge by applying social matching as a technical and intellectual framework for connecting peers for mentorship in online health communities. In partnership with an online cancer community, the investigators are conducting a series of three studies that: (1) Identifying critical mentorship characteristics through a comparative study of automated text extraction as contrasted with to direct user entry of data, (2) Developing tools that connect peers for mentorship through rapid prototyping and usability testing with cancer patients, and (3) Assessing the value of matching for peer mentoring through an online community-based field evaluation.

The results from this research are expected to significantly improve the way people obtain peer help when faced with a health problem. Through a deeper understanding of patients' support needs, this project will use rich online community data to provide tailored recommendations of suitable peer mentors. This work advances knowledge of collaboration in online communities broadly and will translate to other patient services, such as face-to-face support groups. These contributions are significant because they offer patients crucial support strategies in an increasingly burdened healthcare system. Matchmaking among individuals with shared circumstances helps newcomers glean tailored insights into "what to expect" and helps those with experience to share their valuable expertise by "giving back". Thus, this work boosts our current understanding of the underlying processes and informs future research and development in technology that enhances the health and wellbeing of citizens by empowering peer mentorship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed innovative methods for facilitating peer mentoring in on-line peer health communities. In partnership with an online cancer community CancerConnect.com, project objectives were to (1) develop new techniques to identify community members who have critical mentorship characteristics (2) develop novel social matching tools that connect community participants with each other for peer mentorship, and (3) assess the value of social matching for peer mentorship in online health communities. Project activities included the application of natural language processing to unstructured online community data, the application of principles from user-centered design and social matching theory to enable the development of mentor profiles and the social matching of peer mentors to other users in online health communities.

 

Significant results supported by this award include design, development, and validation of user profiles extracted automatically from patient-generated text in online health communities and using those profiles to match patients with online peer mentors. This work resulted in generalizable text extraction methods for online community text, insights into the needs and design preferences of cancer patients for mentor matching through digital tools, and characterizations of online community member roles and contributions from community exchanges.  

 

Applying social matching theory to online health communities contributed an understanding of what it takes to establish deep mentoring connections among online peers. Findings contributed generalizable techniques and insights for leveraging rich online community data to facilitate patient-centered support through social recommendations for cancer patients. These contributions advance the fields of medical informatics and human-computer interaction.

 

More broadly, making it easy to connect online individuals with shared circumstances helps newcomers glean tailored insights into ‘what to expect’ and helps those with experience to share their valuable expertise by ‘giving back’. These benefits have potential to enhance health and wellbeing. Project contributions are significant by offering an increasingly burdened healthcare system innovative strategies for crucial patient support.

 

This award supported thesis work of two doctoral students and two postdocs. In addition, four undergraduates were funded under two Research Experiences for Undergraduates supplements for this project. In total, this project resulted in 20 peer-reviewed publications in fields of medical informatics and human-computer interaction: 4 journal articles, 8 full-length conference proceedings, 6 conference abstracts, a conference workshop, and a book chapter. Among these publications were 2 best paper awards. The specific communities in which these publications are disseminated span medical informatics and human-computer interaction fields.
